metadata.title: Telehealth Use and Hospital Readmission Rates in Long-Term Care Facilities in Southeastern Minnesota during the COVID-19 Pandemic

abstract.text: Objective: To determine if the length of telehealth visit predicted risk of hospital readmission at 30 days at skilled nursing facilities (SNF) in southeastern Minnesota during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Materials and Methods: This was a retrospective cohort study conducted in SNFs located in southeastern Minnesota from March 2020 through July 2020. The primary outcomes included hospitalization within 30 days of a video visit with a secondary outcome of number of provider video visits conducted during SNF stay. The primary predictor was duration of video visit, and we collected other known predictors for hospitalization. We used chi square for categorical variables and multivariant conditional logistical regression.

: We included 722 patients (average age of 82.8 years (10.8)). 76 SNF residents (10.5%) were re-hospitalized within 30 days. The average length of video visit was 34.0 minutes (22.7) in admitted residents compared to 30.0 min (15.9) in non-admitted residents. After full adjustment, there was no difference in video visit duration between admitted and non-admitted residents (OR 1.01 with 95% CI of 0.99-1.03). The number of subsequent provider video visits was 2.26 (1.9) in admitted residents versus 1.58 (1.6), which was significant after adjustment (OR 1.17 with 95% CI of 1.02-1.34). Conclusions: There was no difference in the length of video visit for hospitalized SNF residents versus those who were not within 30 days of a video visit. There were more visits in residents with hospital readmission. This may reflect the acuity of care for patients requiring hospital stay. More research is needed to determine the ideal use of telehealth during the COVID-19 pandemic in the PALTC environment. ERA Elder risk assessment PALTC Post-acute and long-term care SNF Skilled nursing facility J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 2003;51(6):761-767. 9. Bokolo AJ. Exploring the adoption of telemedicine and virtual software for care of outpatients during and after COVID-19 pandemic. Ir J Med Sci. 2021;190(1):1-10. J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

body_text.text: Telemedicine, defined as the use of real-time video-audio equipment by physicians to provide medical assessments to those in remote areas, 1 has been demonstrated to be an effective means of providing medical care in several different settings [2] [3] [4] [5] including management of chronic asthma, diabetes mellitus and Parkinson's disease. The utility of telehealth in in post-acute and long-term care settings (hereafter PALTC) has also been demonstrated as well. 6 During the COVID-19 pandemic, it became quickly apparent that the aged population was at the highest risk for clinical morbidity and mortality 7 from the coronavirus disease, also called COVID-19.

Multiple factors, such as physical co-location of residents, vulnerability of resident population and staffing challenges, make skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) particularly at risk for rapid spread of infection, particularly those related to droplet or aerosols; this has been amply demonstrated with influenza and RSV. 8 Furthermore, due to uncertainty on the virulence and fatality of an unknown virus and future demands, there was need to protect the limited resource of healthcare workers who work across facilities in this setting.

The use of telemedicine has become one method to reduce potential spread of COVID-19 from staff to patients and vice versa in PALTC. With this consideration in mind, health systems rapidly developed telehealth programs. As many of these telemedicine programs were instituted in the setting of a public health emergency, many questions emerged about the optimal use of telemedicine 9,10 as well as patient privacy, 11 among many others. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, studies have suggested that recurrent medical visits (including emergency department visits) 12 was associated with increased hospital readmission rates-many of which could have been avoided. 13 Given the need to avoid unnecessary hospital admissions during the COVID-19 pandemic, this study sought to evaluate if time of telemedicine visit could predict hospital readmission at 30 days. We also considered the number of video visits following the initial visit. The primary aim of this study therefore J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f is to determine the association between the duration of the initial video visit with a provider and subsequent 30-day hospitalization in patients admitted to a SNF facility. The secondary aim is to determine the association between subsequent visits after the video visit and 30-day hospitalization in patients admitted to SNF.

This was a retrospective cohort study. The study was reviewed by the Mayo Clinic IRB and was approved. The study was also reviewed by the Mayo Clinic COVID-19 access committee and was approved by that committee. The study was conducted according to the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. 14

The study population included patients who were dismissed from the hospital and were admitted for PALTC. All nursing home patients from March 2020 until July 2020 were potentially included for the study. We conducted our study in 14 nursing homes in Southeastern Minnesota who were followed by Senior Services providers of the department of Community Internal Medicine. The population in Southeastern Minnesota generally represents the population of the upper Midwest. 15 The exclusion criteria included the lack of an index hospitalization or an index video visit. Residents were also excluded if they refused medical record review. 16

The nursing home practice for the Mayo Clinic Rochester practice follows a model of a dedicated Senior Services division who specialize in the PALTC practice. Twenty-three physicians (including resident physicians) and seventeen advanced practice providers (APP) conducted the video visits. management depending upon illness. 17 The Senior Services division provides coordination for recommendations on standard practice, protocols, staffing and guidance for facilities. Specially, many of the protocols involve admission orders and infection control.

The primary intervention was the use of telemedicine for initial and subsequent provider visits for patients admitted to skilled nursing facility after declaration of COVID-19 as a pandemic. With COVID-19, the facilities in Southeastern Minnesota adopted best practices to reduce spread of COVID-19 through telemedicine. 18 The practice used iPads with InTouch software (Teledoc Health, Santa Barbara, CA, USA), which was the standard platform for the clinical practice. This platform used video visit only without peripheral devices. The nursing facilities provided tele presenters (often nurses) to facilitate the visit with the resident. All providers were given education on the use of the InTouch software.

The primary outcome was 30-day hospitalization following dismissal from the hospital. The outcome was determined using hand abstraction from the electronic medical record. We used the dismissal date as the index time for starting 30-day rehospitalization.

Our primary predictor for readmission included the length of the video visit and the number of provider video visits following the initial video visit. We determined the length of the video visit using hand abstraction of provider-reported time of the visit in the medical record. . Recording time was a primary method of billing the encounter for the resident; thus, this was recorded in the clinical note. We determined the number of video visits performed over 30 days after hospital discharge. These were determined using hand abstraction and were based upon billed encounters with the resident.

J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Patient demographics, including age (as continuous variable in years), sex (female versus other), marital status (married versus other), race (non-white versus white) and interpreter status (yes or no).

We abstracted education level, which was categorized as less than high school, high school graduate, college, or college graduate and more than college. We also reported Elder Risk Assessment (ERA), which accounts for previous hospitalization comorbid health issues and demographic factors. 19 We also reported the presence or absence of medical comorbidities including diabetes, heart failure and dementia but did not utilize all the ERA criterion. This information was obtained from the electronic health record. We also reported the number of medications that the nursing home resident was using.

Descriptive statistics were utilized to define the study cohort of post-acute SNF residents who received a video visit during the specified time frame. We used Wilcoxon nonparametric test of two means. As a secondary analysis, we compared the number of video visits with a provider in 30 days in the hospitalized group compared to those without hospitalization and used Wilcoxon test. We analyzed the remainder of the predictors and reported significance using either Wilcoxon test if continuous or Pearson Chi Square if categorical. After univariable analysis, we used logistic regression to determine significance of individual predictors and high video visit time use. Those factors with a p value <0.05 were be considered significant to be included in the regression. We created a final model using age, sex, ERA score and significant factors to determine a fully adjusted model for that are significant for both time of video visit and number of video visits.

We initially had 1006 patients who had a billed visit for nursing home care after a hospitalization. Of those, 904 had given research authorization for medical record use. Among patients with authorization, 722 patients had a video visit. In the overall cohort, the average age was 82.8 years (SD 10.8 years). The cohort was 65.4% female, and 96.1% of the cohort were white. Only 0.8% J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f needed an interpreter for the medical visit and 49.9% had a high school education or less. In the overall cohort, 76 of the 722 (10.5%) patients had a 30-day hospital readmission. There were no differences between hospitalized and referent group regarding sex, marital status, race, ethnicity, interpreter use, or educational level. We noted a statistically significant increase in the number of medications in the patients who were hospitalized (17.8 medications (8.6)) versus those who were not hospitalized after video visits (15.2 medications (15.2(6.4)) (p value=0.03). Residents with diabetes were also significantly more likely to be readmitted to the hospital (48.7%) when compared to those without diabetes (35.1%). Dementia was a protective factor for hospital readmission, with 43.5% of patients within the group without hospitalization when compared to 25.0% in those with a hospitalization after a video visit (Table 1 ).
In the unadjusted analysis, we did not find a difference between video visit length in admitted residents with 34.0 min (22.7) versus those who were not admitted with 30.0 min. (15.9) (p=0.30).

We found that there were greater number of video visits in admitted patients at 2.26 (1.9) versus 1.58 visits in patients not admitted (p=0.002). We also found that the average age in the hospitalized cohort was 78.8 years (SD 11.1) compared to 83.2 years (SD 10.7) in the referent group (p=0.0006) ( Table 2) .

After full adjustment, there was still no difference in video visit length between hospitalized versus not hospitalized residents with an odds ratio of 1.01 (95% CI 0.99-1.03). Fully adjusted number of visits were higher in hospitalized residents compared to non-hospitalized with an odds ratio of 1.17 (95% CI 1.02-1.34) ( Table 3 ).

In this study of 722 nursing home residents admitted for post-acute care, we did not find a difference in video visit length between those hospitalized and the referent group without hospitalization within 30 days. This indicates that the hospitalized group did not have a longer or shorter visit. We are encouraged that the length of time of video visit was not shorter in hospitalized J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f patients. In ambulatory patients, the median length of time was 15.7 minutes to cover 6 topics in one study; 20 however, we do not fully know how many topics were covered during our visits. We found the overall rate of hospital readmissions was lower than we have seen historically in our population. In our previous studies, we found that the hospital readmission rate overall was 18.2%, 17 whereas readmission in our study was 10.5%. This reduction in hospital readmission likely reflects the changes in hospital admission practices with COVID-19 versus the efficacy of the telemedicine visit practice.

For our secondary outcomes, we found an increased number of visits between the hospitalized group and the referent group with an extra ½ visit a month. We are encouraged that providers used telemedicine to provide care to those complicated residents or residents most at risk for hospitalization. The patients in the hospitalized group were younger, prescribed more medications and had a higher rate of diabetes mellitus when compared to the referent group. Thus this group may require more visits and care. Our group has previously studied the ERA index and found that diabetes, along with other comorbid conditions, raised the risk of both nursing home admission and 2year mortality rate. 19 Additionally, scoring tools, such as the Probability of Repeat Admissions questionnaire (Pra), utilize diabetes as one of the major risks for recurrent hospitalization. 19, 21 Therefore, our finding that more of the patients that requested hospitalization suffered from diabetes mellitus is consistent with prior studies. Our findings are also consistent with multiple studies that have identified polypharmacy as a risk factor for hospitalization, longer length of hospital stay and mortality risk in older patients. [22] [23] [24] The lower readmission rate of 10.2% overall likely reflects the dramatic change in hospitalization and rehospitalization during COVID 19. The patterns of hospital readmission changed after COVID 19 became an important cause of hospitalization. 25 We had numerous learning experiences implementing telemedicine in a short time during COVID-19 that are not captured in our study. Commonly identified challenges in video-based J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f telemedicine include issues with connectivity, privacy, use of equipment, payment and performing the visit itself. We certainly experienced many of those challenges including getting equipment, connectivity and tele-presenting the visit. The guarantee of patient privacy and security of information when utilizing video telehealth modalities is an issue of high priority and we used an iPad with InTouch program which ensured privacy standards and provided an encrypted network for video telehealth visits. HIPAA-based standardized privacy protocols for telehealth use has been recommended 26, 27 to ensure patient privacy standards, though there are currently no unified federally mandated guidelines for telehealth use in skilled nursing facilities, with considerable state-wide variation. We adhered to the privacy protocols for telehealth to ensure privacy of protected health information.

There are several important limitations in our study. Firstly, our sample size was smaller than anticipated due to patients either not giving consent for research purposes or because they did not receive a video visit during the specified time frame (for example, those who were evaluated by an inperson provider). The results of this study were determined by hand abstraction, and, though careful efforts were made to keep the abstraction consistent (i.e., how to indicate missing information, decision to include a video visit if it fell on the last day of data collection, etc), human error is always a possibility. This information was not directly abstracted from EPIC, as billing time was not reviewed in the completed encounter. We relied upon provider estimation of time during the encounter which could present some potential recall issues. In terms of bias, it is possible that information bias played a role in the results of this study, as there were instances in which there was no indication for the length of video visit. Selection bias was unlikely to be a significant source of bias in this study, as all individuals who met the criteria for inclusion were analyzed. From the perspective of generalizability, this is also a limitation of this study, as the population was overwhelmingly white (96.1%). Though approximately 84% of Minnesota's population is white by the 2019 census, 32 our study consisted of more white individuals than the state average. This may limit generalizability to areas in which there is more diversity in nursing home settings. Other limitations included that we J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f were only able to evaluate at the duration of the visit and the scope of this study did not include reviewing the content clinical review and information exchange during the visit as additional quality metrics. Overall, this study demonstrates the ongoing need for further evaluation of the use of telehealth in PALTC to further assess many of these remaining questions.

In this study of 722 SNF patients, we did not find a difference in the length of video visit for those residents who were hospitalized and those who were not within 30 days after a video visit, though the residents who were hospitalized overall had more video visits than those who were not hospitalized.
More research will be needed to determine the ideal means to use telehealth in the skilled nursing care, especially during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic threat. J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f
